title: Probability of Basketball Scores Above 163 Total Points
question_text:
Suppose Jane is interested in the total number of points scored in Division I NCAA college basketball games. She takes a look at several years of data and finds this distribution is approximately normal with a mean of $154\text{ points}$ and standard deviation of $9\text{ points}$.
Using the empirical rule, what is the probability of finding a random game where the total points scored is $163$ or greater?
solution:
The empirical rule says that if the data is approximately normal, $68\%$ of the data will be within one standard deviation while $95\%$ of the data will be within two standard deviations, and $99.7\%$ of the data will be within three standard deviations of the mean.

This problem shows the value $163$ exactly one standard deviation above the mean as:

$$\frac{(163-154)}{9} = 1$$

Therefore, $68\%$ of games score between $145$ and $163\text{ points } (\text{Mean} + 1 \text{ SD})$.

Using complementary probabilities, $100\%-68\%$ = $32\%$ of the data must be outside this range. Since the normal distribution is symmetric, $16\%$ of observations must be less than $145$, and $16\%$ of observations must be greater than $163$.

Thus, the correct answer is Choice 'C'.
